title: 106_s2261
content:
The "Industry Training Consortia Act" defines terms like "employer" and "Secretary" and authorizes skill grants. The "Industry Training Consortia Act" authorizes grants for consortia of employers to develop training programs for specific occupations, aiming to enhance U.S. competitiveness. Eligible entities must include at least 10 employers or nonprofit organizations with common industry or skill needs. The Industry Training Consortia Act authorizes grants for consortia of employers to develop training programs for specific occupations. Eligible entities must include representatives from labor organizations, state and local government agencies, and education organizations. Priority is given to entities where a majority of representatives represent small-business concerns. Grants provided may not exceed $1,000,000 for any fiscal year. SEC. 102. APPLICATION.

Eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant under section 101. The application must be submitted in the required time, manner, and contain necessary information.

SEC. 103. USE OF AMOUNTS. The Secretary may only grant funds to eligible entities if they agree to develop an employer-led education and training program focused on skills related to technology. This program should address employer needs and market demand in specific occupations, including assessing training needs and developing skill standards. The eligible entity must focus on developing curriculum, training methods, acquiring training equipment, identifying education providers, creating apprenticeship programs, and assisting member employers with human resource development planning. Additionally, they must meet the requirement of developing employer-led education and training programs tailored to technology skills and specific occupational needs. The eligible entity must focus on developing curriculum, training methods, acquiring training equipment, identifying education providers, creating apprenticeship programs, and assisting member employers with human resource development planning. They are also required to provide performance outcome measures for the program and education providers, submit reports on best practices, and allocate up to 10% of the grant for administrative costs. SEC. 104. REQUIREMENT OF MATCHING FUNDS. The Secretary cannot grant funds unless the eligible entity agrees to provide non-Federal contributions of at least $2 for every $1 of Federal funds, with $1 of each $2 coming from employers with representatives on the entity. SEC. 105. LIMIT ON ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES. SEC. 105. LIMIT ON ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES. The Secretary can use up to 5% of funds for federal administrative costs related to grants and to maintain an electronic clearinghouse. SEC. 106. INFORMATION AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary will provide information and technical assistance to eligible entities on best practices. SEC. 107. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $50,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2001-2003. TITLE II--PLANNING GRANTS

SEC. 201. AUTHORIZATION.

The Secretary of Commerce, with the Secretary of Labor, provides grants to States for planning consortia formation, not exceeding $500,000 per year.

SEC. 202. APPLICATION.

States must submit an application to receive grants under section 201.

SEC. 203. REQUIREMENT OF MATCHING FUNDS. SEC. 203. REQUIREMENT OF MATCHING FUNDS.

States must agree to provide non-Federal contributions equal to $1 for each $1 of Federal funds received under a grant. 

SEC. 204. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$50,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2001 to implement this title.
